channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran Pushes Ahead With Nuclear Plant That Worries West
item.description: Iran is pressing ahead with the construction of a research reactor that could offer it a second way of producing material for a nuclear bomb, a U.N. report showed on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Lede: London Attack Suspect Recorded Statement After Killing, Video Shows
item.description: Moments after a man was hacked to death on a street in London on Wednesday, one of two suspects in the attack approached a witness who was recording the scene on video and asked to make a statement.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: One of two suspects in a deadly attack in London on Wednesday spoke to a witness who was recording video in the immediate aftermath of the killing.

item.title: U.S. Acknowledges Killing 4 Americans in Drone Strikes
item.description: One day before President Obama is due to deliver a speech on national security, his administration formally acknowledged that the United States had killed American citizens in Yemen and Pakistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Lens Blog: Angelos Tzortzinis's Photos of Growing Desperation in Greece
item.description: In Greece, the perils of a drawn-out debt crisis are imprinted on its younger population — whose unemployment numbers are soaring — who turn to selling their bodies for money and to a dangerous, cheap new street drug for escape.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Officials Meet After Brutal Attack in Southeast London
item.description: Britain’s top security officials gathered Wednesday evening after police officers shot two men suspected of killing what some reports identified as a British soldier.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: A police forensics investigator, center, approached a crime scene where one man was killed on Wednesday in London.

item.title: Report on Bangladesh Building Collapse Finds Widespread Blame
item.description: The Rana Plaza building was constructed with substandard materials and in blatant disregard for building codes, the high-level government report concluded.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A report blamed the mayor for wrongly granting construction approvals and recommended charges for the Rana Plaza building's owner.

item.title: Costa Concordia Captain to Be Tried for Manslaughter
item.description: A trial is to begin on July 9 for Francesco Schettino, captain of the doomed Costa Concordia, which ran aground off the coast of Tuscany in January 2012, killing 32.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: London Killing Prompts Emergency Meeting
item.description: British Prime Minister David Cameron called an emergency security meeting on Wednesday after a man was killed near an army barracks in London, and two men were shot and wounded by police.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Gold Mine Discovered in Northwest China
item.description: The mine is believed to have gold reserves of at least 53 tons, worth about $3.2 billion, according to the state news agency.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 22
item.description: A religious procession in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women carrying earthenware pots containing holy water, during a religious procession in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

item.title: North Korean Leader Sends Envoy to China
item.description: Kim Jong-un sent a top official to China as ties between the two countries remained strained over Pyongyang’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 22
item.description: Animal welfare in China; forgery on the New York art market; U.S. drone strikes; Apple’s tax deal in Ireland; Ai Weiwei’s first heavy-metal video; Global Soccer.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Looking for food at a bear farm. The treatment of the animals has drawn protests from critics.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Vote Allegations Rattle Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The Eurovision Song Contest is an annual festival of kitsch and glamour, with entrants across Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals. But, once again this year, politics were not far below the surface.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Denmark's Emmelie de Forest, this year's Eurovision winner.

item.title: Egyptian President Announces Release of Officers Kidnapped in Sinai
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi said seven Egyptian security officers who were abducted nearly a week ago had been freed, ending increasing anxiety over the government’s grip on security in the region.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Letter from India: In Cricket Scandal, Revelations on India
item.description: Saying cricket can explain India is a tired literary cliché. But this year's Indian Premier League scandal says a lot about modern Indian society.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Afghanistan’s Karzai Says ‘No Circumstances’ Allow Him to Seek Another Term
item.description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has sought to dispel talk that he will find a way to stay in power beyond his constitutionally mandated two terms.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: India Ink: A Photographer’s Dispatch from Mt. Everest
item.description: A series of images capture a recent Indian expedition to the Everest.
item.dc:creator: By PERCY FERNANDEZ

item.title: Inquiry Set in Fatal Mining Collapse in Indonesia
item.description: Investigators will be appointed by the Indonesian government and the American company that owns the mine.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Tensions Flare in Asian Seas, Now Involving Taiwan
item.description: ‘Han chauvinism’ and ‘a lack of worldliness’ are two differing explanations for the Taiwan government’s hardline stance in a recent row with the Philippines over the killing of a Taiwanese fisherman in disputed waters.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Residents of Taichung in Taiwan, led by a Taiwanese lawmaker, Lu Shou-yen (center, in purple shirt,) chant slogans demanding an apology from the Philippine government for the death of a Taiwanese fisherman.

item.title: Square Feet: Ambitious Paris Project Takes Shape in the Suburbs
item.description: The 133-acre Clichy Batignolles, named for the adjoining neighborhoods in northwest Paris, will include offices, housing, a park and a court complex.
item.dc:creator: By PETER SIGAL
item.media:description: Renderings of two residential buildings, the left one designed by the firm of Christian Biecher, the other by MAD.

item.title: In Europe, a Fed President Urges Quantitative Easing
item.description: James Bullard, a member of the Federal Reserve’s policy committee, warned Europe of becoming trapped in the economic stasis from which Japan is only now emerging.
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: India Ink: Kashmir Pressing Delhi for Aid for Quake-Hit Victims
item.description: More than three weeks after an earthquake hit the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, victims await government support toward rehabilitation.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Patients were evacuated from a hospital in the town of Bhaderwah in Jammu and Kashmir after an earthquake struck the region on May 1.

item.title: Aleksei Balabanov, Russian Film Director, Dies at 54
item.description: Mr. Balabanov’s movies offered up hit men, corrupt government officials and plenty of corpses.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Heinrich Rohrer, Physicist Who Won Nobel, Dies at 79
item.description: Dr. Rohrer helped invent the scanning tunneling microscope, which made it possible to see individual atoms and move them around.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Heinrich Rohrer, left, and Gerd Binnig, his fellow Nobelist, in 1986. The men invented the scanning tunneling microscope.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Security Forces Fire on Funeral
item.description: Egyptian officials say soldiers and police officers mistakenly fired on a Bedouin funeral in the Sinai Peninsula during a search for kidnapped security personnel.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
